caseTitle: LAND ADMINISTRATION IN NORTHERN GHANA [1980] VOL. XII RGL 10
summary: This legal commentary examines the historical development and impact of land administration policies in Northern Ghana, contrasting them with systems in the rest of the country. The author, Agbosu L. K., highlights how colonial-era Public Lands Bills of 1894 and 1897, though defeated in southern regions due to opposition from native elites and European interests, were effectively implemented in the Northern Territories. This led to a dual land administration system in Ghana. In the North, land rights were delinked from tribal membership and instead tied to colonial citizenship, minimizing title disputes and speculation. The government assumed control through agencies like the Lands and Survey Departments, reducing the role of traditional authorities. The article emphasizes that this system significantly reduced boundary conflicts and litigationâ€”problems prevalent elsewhere in Ghana. Despite its success, the author warns that the Northern model is under threat of abolition in favor of less effective southern systems, which could reintroduce title insecurity and administrative inefficiencies.
verdict: The article concludes that the land administration system in Northern Ghana, rooted in the principles of the abortive 1890s land reforms, has been relatively successful in ensuring land tenure security and minimizing disputes.
winningSide: Proponents of the Northern land administration model
rationaleHighlights: Colonial land policies created long-term inconsistencies in Ghana's land administration.
The abortive Public Lands Bills of 1894 and 1897 sought to formalize traditional land systems but were withdrawn due to native and European opposition.
Northern Ghana adopted policies based on the principles of the failed Bills, leading to reduced title uncertainty and litigation.
In Northern Ghana, land rights became based on citizenship rather than tribal membership, abolishing inter-tribal boundary disputes.
Government agencies took over land control functions from traditional authorities in the North.
The Northern system is at risk of being replaced by less effective systems from southern Ghana.
